titlestmt.title: PCT 46: Wisahketchahk Visits his Little Brother, the Skunk
titlestmt.author: Coming-Day

bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: PCT 46: Wisahketchahk visits his little brother, the skunk

p.seg: kîtahtawê wîsahkêcâhk owîkimâkanah wîcêwêw , êh-pimipicicik . Once upon a time Wisahketchahk with his wife was moving camp.
mâka mîna nôhtêhkatêw . As usual, he was hungry.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp . Then at one time, he saw a tipi
êkotah êh-takohtêt , wâpamêw nâpêwa , pêyak iskwêwa owîkimâkaniyiwa . When he walked up to the place, we saw a man and a woman, the man's wife.
tawâw , tawâw ! itik . “Come in, come in!” the other said to him.

hâ , nisîm , itwêw ,
ôtah êcik ôma êh-ayâyan ? “Why, Brother,” he cried, “and so this is where you are staying!”
hêhag , itik . “Yes,” answered the other.
pîhtokêwak . They went in.
hêhêhêy ! namoya mistahi ihtakon ka-mîciyahk , itwêyiwa . “Well, well, well! There isn't much for us to eat,” said the man.
êkwah asamik ; mîcisôwak . Then they gave him food; they ate.
êkotah ayâwak . They stayed there.
piyis tipiskâw . At last night came.
hâw , nôtokêsiw , wêpahtakahikê , itwêyiwa osîma ; “Come, Old Woman, sweep out the tent,” said Wisahketchahk's younger brother;

seg.gloss: “My big brother has been going hungry, you know.

p.seg: ntômâtânik mostoswak , itwêyiwa . Let us call some buffalo,” said he.
tâpwê wêpahtakahikêw . Accordingly, she swept.
êkwah oyaskinahêw , êh-pîhtwâcik . Then he filled the pipe, and they smoked.
êh-kîsi-pîhtwâcik , êkwah otinêyiwa sîsîkwana . When they had smoked, he took a rattle.

seg.gloss: “Now, Big Brother, you too are to sing.”
“Yes!”

p.seg: êkwah nikamoyiwa , sîsikwanah êh-âpacihâyit . Then the other sang, using the rattle.
â , kahkiyaw nikamôwak , piyisk kinwês ; piyisk pôyowak ; They all sang, for a long time; at last they ceased;
kawisimôwak ; nipâwak . they went to bed; they slept.
êh-wâpahk kîksêpâ , êh-wayawît awa kisêyiniw , kisiwâk wâpamêw mostoswah . In the morning early, when the old man went outside, he saw the buffalo close by.

ômis îtwêw :
wâh , nistêsê , ksiwâk ayâwak mostoswak ! itwêyiwa , êh-otinâyit sîsîkwanah . He said, “Hullo, Brother, the buffalo are close by!” and as he spoke, he took up his rattle.
â , nsîm , nîst êtokê nik-êtohtân , itêw . “Oh, Brother, don't you suppose I could go there, too?” he asked him.
namoya , itik , êh-wayawiyit , êh-itohtêyit pîhtokahân . “No,” the other told him, and went out of the tent, to the buffalo-close.

êkotê ê-tohtêyit , âkawâyihk ohci kitâpamêw , kâ-wâpamât skwâhtêmihk êh-nahapiyit ôh ôsîma , êh-nikamoyit . When the other went there, he watched him from behind something, and there he saw his little brother seat himself and sing.

mayaw êh-pêhtahkik ôki mostoswak , sêmâk pê-sipwêhtêwak , ôhi ksêyiniwah êh-moskîstawâyit . As soon as those buffalo heard it, at once they started off in that direction, going straight for the old man.

awa kisêyiniw ômis îtwêw :
îtawiyaw pimohtêh ! itêw ôhi mostoswah . Then the old man spoke as follows: “Walk along at both sides!” he said to the buffalo.
tâpwêh âyîtaw pimohtêyiwah , êh-pîhtokêyit pîhtokahânihk . And really, they walked past on either side of him, and entered the buffalo-pound.

êkosi êkwah acicisiniyiwah ôhi kisêyiniwa , êh-kitâpamât awa wîsahkêcâhk osîmah , êh-pwêkitôyit . Thereupon that old man got down on all fours with his head to the ground, and, Wisahketchahk all the while watching his younger brother, broke wind.
kahkiyaw nipahêyiwa . He killed them all.
akâwâtamawêw , êh-wâpamât êh-tôtamiyit osîma . He envied his younger brother for what he saw him do.
êkosi kîwêw awa wîsahkêcâhk . So the Wisahketchahk went back to the tipi.

êh-apit , kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit osîma ,
hâ , nistêsê , mistahi êkwah ka-mîcisonânaw ; mihcêt nnipahâwak mostoswak , êh-itikot . As he sat there, his brother cam in, and, “Ho, Big Brother, now we shall eat a plenty; I have killed many buffalo,” he told him.
hay hay hay ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ; “Splendid!” said Wisahketchahk;
hah , kimôhkomân otinah ; ntawih-wînihtâkêtân , êh-itikot . and the other said to him, “Come, take your knife; let us go do the butchering.”
tâpwê kahkiyaw tohtêwak , ôki mîna iskwêwak . So they all went there, the women too.
êh-takohtêt , mihcêt mostoswah wâpamêw , êh-pimisiniyit . When he got there, he saw many buffalo lying there.
wah-wînihtâkêwak ; kahkiyaw wiyanihêwak ; êkwah awatâwak wiyâsah . They cleaned one after the other; they cut them all up; then they carried off the meat.
êkwah mistahi ayâw mîciwin , êkwah owîkimâkanah êy-osîhtâyit kâhkêwakwah . so now he had plenty of food, and his wife set about making dried meat.
mâka mîna akâwâtamawêw ômah k-êsi-nipahâyit . But still he envied the other his way of killing them.
êkwah oyaskinahêw otôspwâkanah , êh-pasikôt , êh-miyât ôh ôsîmah . so he filled his pipe and rose to his feet, and gave it to his little brother.

omis îtwêw :
nisîm , kitimâkêyimin ; he spoke as follows: “Little Brother, take pity on me;
kitakâwâtamâtn kitisi-minahôwin , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk , êh-mâtot . I long for you power of killing game in this way,” said Wisahketchahk, weeping.

piyisk ,
ahag , itik . At last the other said, “Yes,” to him.

êkosi êkwah ê-nahapit , ômis îtik :
hâw , nistêsê , iyikohk wî-sipwêhtêyinih ; When accordingly he had sat down, the other said to him, “Now, Big Brother, wait until you are ready to leave;
misawâc mêkwâc mistahi kitayânânaw wiyâs , êh-itikot . for the present we have in any case a great deal of meat,” the other told him.
hâw , nisîm , ôtêh pimohtêwak ntawâsimisak , itêw ; “Well, Little Brother, over yonder my children are walking along,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “With reference to this very day, 'In that place I shall see you,' I told them.

p.seg: êkos ânohc ka-sipwêhtêyân , itêw . So now is when I must leave,” he told him.

nâh , itik owîkimâkanah ,
mistah ômah wiyâs kitayânânaw ; mâka kitawâsimisinawak êkota ka-pêhikonawak . “Nonsense,” his wife said to him, “Here we have all this meat; after all, our children will wait for us over there.”

seg.gloss: “What matter, since my brother is going to give me his hunting-power?

p.seg: wâpamâyahkwâwi kitawâsimisinawak , êkotê mihcêt nka-nipahâwak mostoswak , itwêw . When we see our children, I shall kill plenty of buffalo over there,” said he.
âhag , itik owîkimâkanah . “Very well,” his wife answered him.

êkosi ômis îtik osîmah :
hâw , nistêsê , kâ-wîh-miyitân ntisi-minahôwin ! Then his younger brother spoke to him as follows: “Now then, Big Brother, I shall give you my power of killing game in this way!”
êkwah wayawîwak , ôhpimêh êh-itohtêcik . Then they left the tipi and walked off to one side.

seg.gloss: “There, Brother, sid down here!”

p.seg: nahapiw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk sat down.

seg.gloss: “Get down on all fours!”

p.seg: nêt ôtêh osîmah êkos îsi acicisiniyiwa , ê-kitâpamikot . over at this end his brother crouched in the same way, and kept looking at him.

seg.gloss: “Big Brother, pull aside your breech-clout!”

p.seg: wîhkwatinêw . He pulled it aside.

seg.gloss: “Pull your buttocks like this!”

p.seg: êkwah wîsahkêcâhk êkosi ispitam sôhkih ; Then Wisahketchahk stretched them hard;
sôhk êkosi êh-tôtahk , pwêkitoyiwa . when he had done it properly, the other broke wind.
sêmâk wiya wîsahkêcâhk kwâskwêkocin . At once Wisahketchahk flew up into the air.
wâhyaw pahkisin ; wîsakisin . Far off he fell; he had a bad fall.

pasikôw , êh-itohtêt ,
hâw , pêyakwâw , nistêsê ! êh-itikot . He got up and walked back, and, “Fall, once more!” said the other to him.
êkwah kostam . Now he was afraid of it.

seg.gloss: “Come, Big Brother!”

p.seg: piyis tâpwêhtam . At last he obeyed.
âsay mîna acicisin , âsay mîna êh-pwêkicitikot . Again he crouched down, and again the other broke wind at him.
wâhyaw mîna pahkisin . Again he fell far.
êkwah êkotah kinwês nipahisin . Then for a long time he lay there as though dead.
êkosi êkwah pasikôw , êh-ati-sipwêhtêt . Then at last he rose to his feet, and went to leave.

seg.gloss: “There, come, Old Woman, let us go.”

p.seg: sipwêhtêwak . They departed.

wâhyaw êy-îhtâcik ,
hâw , nôtokêsiw , matwân_cî tâpwê êh-miyit kaskitêw ? itwêw ; When they were far from there, “Well, Old Woman, can it be that he really has given me the power?” said he;

seg.gloss: “Suppose I take a trial shot at this grove of trees.”

p.seg: êkâ wiya ! itik owîkimâkanah ; “Don't!” his wife said to him;

seg.gloss: “You will waste it.
Didn't you say we were to get our food from it?”
“Well, perhaps he was trying to fool me.
Do let me make a trial shot.

p.seg: âhci pikoh kotahâskwâtam oma sakâw . Undeterred, he made a trial shot with that grove of trees as his target.
kahkiyaw mistikwah kawiwêpaham . He knocked over all the trees.

seg.q: kâh , tâpw ês âni nimiyik ominahôwin nisîm !
seg.gloss: “What do you think of that! So my little brother did really give me his way of killing game!”

p.seg: êkosi minah âhci piko sipwêhtêw . Then he set out again, as before.
namoya wâhyaw êy-ihtât , kâ-wâpamât ê-misikitiyit asiniyah . He had not gone far, when he saw a big stone.

êhâ , nôtokêsiw , mâhcih nka-kotahâskwân , êh-itwêt ,
êkâ wiyah ! itik owîkimâkanah . “Hey, Old Woman, suppose I do some target-shooting,” he said, and “Do not!” his wife told him.
âhci pikoh pwêkicitêw asiniyah . Over he protest he broke wind at the stone.
pîkopayiyiwa asiniyah . the stone flew to pieces.

seg.gloss: “Well, Old Woman, let us pitch camp;

p.seg: nnôhtêhkatân , itêw . I am hungry,” he said to her.
kîkwayih tê-mîciyahk ? itik . “What are we to eat?” she asked him.
k-ôsîhtânânaw pîhtokahân ; kika-ntomânawak mostoswak , itêw . “Let us build a buffalo-pound; we shall call some buffalo,” he told her.

seg.gloss: “Very well!”

p.seg: kapêsiwak . They pitched camp.

ê-kîsi-mânokêcik , êkwah taw-osîhtâwak pîhtokahân , êkwah ê-tipiskâyik , êh-nikamocik , êh-ntômâcik mostoswah . When they had set up their tipi, they went about building the pound, and them, after dark, they sang to call the buffalo.
êh-wâpahk kîksêpâ , kâ-wâpamât mostoswah . Early in the morning he saw the buffalo.

êkwah sipwêhtêw , iskwâhtêmihk ê-nahapit awa wîsahkêcâhk , êkwah êh-nikamot ,
îtawiyaw pimohtêk ! Then he set out, and sat down in the entrance-way, this Wisahketchahk, and began to sing, “Walk along at either side!”
êh-isi-nikamot , mayaw êh-pêhtâkot mostoswah , pê-sipwêpayiyiwah . When he sang thus, as soon as the buffalo heard him, they started running toward him.

kisiwâk êh-ayâyit ,
tâwâskikan ! êh-itwêt , tâwikipayihik mostoswah . When they were near, he said, “Square in the chest!” and the buffalo ran right into him.
kinwêsk nipahiskâk . For a long time they trampled him out of his senses.
êkwah kitâpamik owîkimâkanah . Then his wife saw him.
êh-kitâpamikot owîkimâkanah , êy-ispahtâyit , pîkonamiyiwa om ôpîhtokahân . When she saw him, she ran there, and broke down his enclosure.
kahkiyaw wayawiyiwa , êh-tapasiyit . All the buffalo ran out.
êkoyikohk êkwah waniskâw , êh-âpisisihk . Only then he got up, having returned to his senses.
êkwah acicipayihôw , êh-pwêkitot . Then he threw himself down on all fours and broke wind.
nama kêkway nipahêw ; âyisk kîh-mêstinam kâ-kotahâskwêt . He killed nothing; for he had wasted it in target-shooting.
atimo-kisêyiniw ! itik owîkimâkanah , êkâ kêkway êh-nipahtât , êh-kîhkâmikot . “Dog of an old man!” his wife said to him, when he killed nothing, and she began to scold him.

seg.gloss: “Well, Old Woman, please, do you run back;
run to my little brother's;
go ask him for some of that game-killing power that he gave me, so that we may use it to get food.”

p.seg: êkwah tâpwê kîwêw awa nôtokêsiw . So the old woman went back.

nêtê êh-takohtêt ,
hâw , nîtim , mistah êh-ma-mâyînikêt kistês , êh-mêstinahk kâ-kîh-miyat kit-ôh-minahot , êh-kâ-kotahâskwêt . When she arrived over yonder, “Well, Brother-in-Law, I have come because your brother, who always makes a bad mess of things, has used up in target-shooting that which you gave him for killing game.

seg.q:
êkwah mînah kinwêsk nipahik mostoswah ,
tâwâskikan ! êh-itwêt ,
êh-wanitônâmoyân , êh-itwêt .
seg.gloss: And, besides, the buffalo knocked him silly for a long time, because he said, ‘Square in the chest!’ and then he said, ‘It was a slip of the tongue.’

seg.q: pikoh ômâ anohc itohtê ; ntawi-ntotamaw nisîm otisi-minahôwin , êy-isit , kâ-pê-sipwêhtêyân .
seg.gloss: ‘Just you now go there; go ask my brother for some of his way of killing game,’ he told me, and that is why I have come here.”

p.seg:
âhag , nîtim , ka-miyitin nîswâw kit-ôh-minahoyan , itêw ; “Very well, Sister-in-Law, I will give you wherewith twice to kill game,” he told her;
âh , âstam ! “Now, come here!”
wayawîwak . They went out of the tent.

seg.gloss: “So then, Sister-in-Law, get down on all fours here!”

p.seg: êkwah acicisiniyiwa . Then he too got down on all fours.

seg.gloss: “Stretch out your buttocks like this!”

p.seg: tâpwê êkosi êh-tôtahk , êh-pwêkicitikot , wâhyaw pahkisin . And really, when she did that way, and he broke wind at her, far off she fell to the ground.

kîhtwâm mîna êkos êh-tôtâkot , êh-pwêkicitikot , kinwêsê kinwêsk nipahisin awa nôtokêsiw . When he did it to here a second time and broke wind at her, for a long, long time the old woman lay senseless. CHECK kinwêsê
iyikohk êh-âpisisihk , kîwêw . When she came back to life, she went back.

êh-takohtêyit , awa wîsahkêcâhk ,
niwîkimâkan , kimiyik cî ? When she arrived, Wisahketchahk, “Wife, did he give you any?”
atimo-kisêyiniw , êh-âyimaniyik êcikw âwa ! itik . “Dog of an old man, and so it is a difficult thing, as it turns out!” she answered him.
êkwah osîhtâwak ômah kâ-kîh-pîkonamiyit pîhtokahân . Then they build up the buffalo-pound which she had pulled down.
êh-kîsihtâcik , êkwah êh-tipiskâyik , êkosi kâ-nikamocik , ê-ntômâcik mostoswah . When they had got it in shape, and night came, they sang to call the buffalo.
tâpwê ê-nipâcik , êh-wâpahk , kîksêpâ , kâ-wâpamât mostoswah . And really, when they had slept, early the next morning, there he saw the buffalo.
êkwah itohtêw awa nôtokêsiw . Then the old woman went over there.
êkwah êyakoh êh-nikamot . Then she sang.
îtawiyaw pimohtê ! itwêw . “Walk along at either side!” were her words.
tâpwê pîhtokêyiwa . Thereupon they went into the pound.
êkwah acicisin ôwa nôtokêsiw , êh-pwêkitot . Then the old woman got down on all fours and broke wind.
kahkiyaw nipahêw mostoswah . She killed all the buffalo.
mistahi miywêyihtam wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was very glad.

êkwah êh-awatâcik wiyâs ,
hâw , nôtokêsiw , pakâhtâkohkê . Then, when they carried in the meat, “Well, Old Woman, boil it in the kettle.
kîh-mîcisoyahkoh , kâhkêwakwah k-ôsîhtânânaw , itêw owîkimâkanah . When we have eaten, we shall prepare jerked meat,” he told his wife.
êhag , itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . “Yes,” said the old woman.
tâpwê êh-kîh-mîcisocik , êkwah osîhtâwak kâhkêwakwah . And so, when they had eaten, they made jerked meat.
akâwâtamawêw ômah kâ-nipahâyit mostoswah owîkimâkanah . He envied his wife the way she had killed the buffalo.
êkwah isîhtâw kâhkêwakwa awa wîsahkêcâhk , êh-atih-akotât mistikohk . And so Wisahketchahk prepared dried meat, hanging it on a tree.

piyisk ê-tipiskâyik ,
hahâw , êkâya nipâh , nôtokêsiw ; kakwê-kîsihtâh kiwiyâsima , itêw . When at last it grew dark, “Now, Old Woman, do not go to sleep; try to finish preparing your meats,” he told her.
tâpwê kapê-tipisk pânisâwêw awa nôtokêsiw . And so that old woman spent the whole night curing meat.
piyisk nôhtêhkwasiw . At last she was sleepy.
êkâya nipâ , niwîkimâkan ! itêw . “Don't go to sleep, Wife!” he told her.
piyisk nipâw awa nôtokêsiw . Finally the old woman fell asleep.
waniskâ , niwîkimâkan ! kipânisâwâ ! iyât-îtâcih , namoya pêkopayiyiwa ; nipâyiwa . Even when he said to her “Get up, Wife! Don't forget your meat-curing!” she did not wake up; she was asleep.
nika-kimotamawâw , itêyihtam , ôma k-ôh-nipahâyit mostoswah . “I will steal it from her,” he thought, meaning that with which she had killed the buffalo.
piyisk oskotâkâsiyiw owîkimâkanah ohpinamwêw , itah k-ôh-pwêkitoyit êkotah êh-itâpit . Finally he lifted up his wife's petticoat, and looked at whence she broke wind.

kâ-wâpahtahk ôma k-ôh-pwêkitôyit , êkwah miscikos otinam , ê-wih-otâskwahamowât , ê-wîh-kimotamawât . When he had caught sight of that from which she broke wind, he took a little stick, meaning to take it from her by means of the stick and to steal it from her.
mayaw ê-waskawiwêpahahk , kâ-pêkopayiyit , êh-pwêkitoyit . Just as he began to twitch the stick, she woke up and broke wind.

mêtoni wâhyaw ihtakocin awa wîsahkêcâhk , ê-pistahokot owîkimâkanah . Off and away, to a great distance, Wisahketchahk went flying, when his wife thus accidentally shot him. LB on {ihtakocin}: Error, for {itakocin}?
itêh êh-pahkisihk , kinwês nipahisin . There he fell to the ground, for a long time he lay as if dead.
atimo-kisêyiniw kâ-môhcôwit , kâ-wiyakihtât ! itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . “Dog of an old man, crazy fool, to waste it like that!” cried the old woman.

êkwah wîsahkêcâhk omis îtwêw :
êh-ati-pasikôt kiwîkimâkan , kotahâskwâtâhkan , ê-kîh-itisk cî nisîm ? Then Wisahketchahk said, “‘When your husband is in the act of getting up, use him as a target for your shots,’ is that what my brother told you to do?”
namoya ; ayisk kimôhcôwin , itik owîkimâkanah . “No, you are crazy, that is all,” his wife answered him.
ayah ês ôhi sikâkwah ôhi kâ-mâh-miyikocik ta-minahocik . It appears that he was the Skunk, he who gave them the power of killing game.
êkosi êkwah êkoyikohk êyôkô âtayôhkêwin . And so this is the end of this sacred story.
